oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Willie Nelson Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Willie Nelson (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Willie Nelson; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Willie Nelson remembers having a cake fight with Richard Pryor and Collie asks if Nelson got to eat any cake -- (00:54) Nelson says "Wow" -- (00:58) Nelson says "So, but" -- (01:01) Nelson says "I feel like that" -- (01:05) Nelson says "Well No" and Collie attempts to inject [indistinguishable audio] -- (01:09) Nelson says "Yeah" -- (01:11) Nelson says "No, no" -- (01:16) Collie exhales -- (01:21) Nelson says "Well" -- (01:23) Nelson says "Ask that again" -- (01:28) Nelson says "Tell me some more about this -- (01:33) Nelson says "Both, yeah yeah" -- (01:37) Nelson says "And he's still that way, he's still" -- (01:43) Nelson says "I think so, I think" -- (01:47) Collie laughs and say "It would have be simplified" and Nelson says "Yeah really" -- (01:54) Nelson says "Don't consciously know that I am" -- (02:00) Nelson says "Yeah, yeah there's a" -- (02:08) Nelson says "Yeah that's true" -- (02:16) Nelson says "I got to talk to him and see if he did that intentionally" -- (02:21) Nelson says "No I'm not excited about it, because its like I say, who knows what is going to happen." -- (02:30) Nelson says "Maybe he's too good to be a great Politian" -- (02:40) Nelson says "Well I think that probably some, all of those things combine" -- (02:50) Nelson says "The record companies are making a big deal out of it; which is fine" -- (02:56) Nelson says "The last I heard, he was still playing Adolf Hofner and the Pearl Wranglers" -- (03:04) Nelson says "That's right" -- (03:10) Nelson says "That's right" -- (03:13) Collie and Nelson share a laugh -- (03:16) Nelson says "Well I'm going to do a show cause" -- (03:21) Nelson says "That's right" -- (03:24) Nelson says "That's right" -- (03:27) Nelson says "True" -- (03:30) Nelson says "He enjoyed it" -- (03:33) Willie Nelson [indistinguishable audio] -- (03:37) Nelson says "Yes, he does; he really does" -- (03:41) Nelson says "Yeah" -- (03:44) Nelson says "Right" -- (03:46) Nelson says "Yeah, that's" -- (03:49) Nelson says "You don't, ever" -- (03:52) Nelson says "Yeah, really" -- (03:55) Nelson says "No, I never did" -- (03:58) Nelson says "Yeah, and also I" -- (04:03) "Yeah quite a few, quite quite a few" -- (04:08) Nelson says "I was living in oh" [indistinguishable audio] -- (04:17) Nelson says "Either way I was" -- (04:20) Oh he sure is; he's from Hildenborough, Whitney" -- (04:28) Nelson says "In other words" -- (04:32) Nelson says "To answer your question, I don't know" -- (04:36) Nelson says "Well" -- (04:40) Nelson says "Well, yeah" -- (04:45) "I'm not smart enough to answer that one" -- (04:49) Nelson says "Probably some of them did" -- (04:52) Nelson says "Yeah" -- (04:55) Nelson says "It doesn't bother me, there's still" -- (05:00) Nelson says "Before, yeah" -- (05:02) Nelson says "It sounds a little strange to say that" -- (05:08) Nelson says "Well we plugged our own songs, is what it amounted to. We became our own critics" -- (05:16) Collie and Nelson talk about how Whitey Shafer would come out to Nelson's shows -- (05:35) Collie questions about, and Nelson tells about his disinterest, when people like to blame Nelson for their issues -- (06:02) Collie and Nelson joke about whether or not Nelson is a 'sex symbol' -- (06:07) Nelson says the girl fans would have to say whether or not he is a 'sex symbol' -- (07:04) Nelson talks about growing up on Bob Wills and Nelson reflects on Tommy Duncan and Wills' music style; Nelson tells about how he booked and recorded with Wills -- (08:28) Nelson tells the first promotion he ever did was for Wills -- (08:37) Nelson reveals how he began playing guitar when he was ten -- (08:53) Nelson tells how his grandparents were music teachers and Collie and Nelson discuss what are 'shape notes' -- (10:22) Nelson discusses going to Wednesday night gospel singing -- (11:01) Nelson and Collie discuss, Nelson's sister, Bobbie Nelson's music talent -- (11:25) Collie has Nelson reflect on how Nelson worked in the fields to make money for school supplies and Nelson tells about how he was a multi-sport athlete -- (12:20) Nelson discusses 'Zeke' his friend that he has had since high school -- (12:57) Nelson and Collie reflect on Nelson's friends' attitude being unchanging from his fame -- (13:50) Nelson tells about his various odd jobs he had, including being an encyclopedia salesman -- (14:47) Nelson reflects about the times he got fired from KRCT and a band -- (15:25) Collie has Nelson reflect on Nelson's disc jockey career -- (16:00) Nelson reveals he had been writing poems and songs since the age of five -- (16:35) "The Storm Within My Heart" is revealed to be Nelson's first recording; Nelson reflects on his relationship with Billy Walker -- (17:40) Nelson discusses the long list of places he lived; additionally, he recalls writing Family Bible and "Night Life" in Houston, Texas -- (18:42) Nelson discusses meeting Hank Cochran, among others, at Tootsies Orchid Lounge; additionally, Nelson discusses the techniques he and others would use to practice prior to bringing songs to a record label -- (20:42) Nelson reflects on how he first became recognized as a song-writer and singer -- (20:52) Nelson reflects on the demand for song-writers and Nelson discusses his reasoning to continue recording -- (21:45) Collie has Nelson reflect on how Chet Atkins created a new guitar Nelson and how Atkins worked to make Nelson successful at RCA Records -- (22:40) Nelson tells how he had left Nashville in order to get closer to his work opportunities in Texas -- (24:41) Collie has Nelson reveal how Nelson got his distinctive style -- (25:23) Collie and Nelson discuss how the fourth of July picnics had an effect on Nelson's career, and Nelson tells how the Armadillo Club was a safe haven for the youthful residents -- (28:30) Collie and Nelson discuss the purpose of Nelson's hair style change; the purpose was to annoy the people who dislike hippies -- (29:27) Nelson explains his hesitation to perform on television -- (31:13) Nelson discusses how he did not have much to talk about on a television show -- (31:30) Nelson and Collie reflect on the colossal moment Nelson was invited on to Johnny Carson's show -- (32:33) Nelson reveals his first duet album with Waylon Jennings and its inspiration coming from the Fourth of July Picnic -- (33:51) Nelson explains how it was necessary, when he originally recorded with Jennings, to do so without record management interference -- (34:26) Collie and Nelson discuss how Robert Redford originally introduced Nelson to movie work with Electric Horseman -- (35:47) Nelson describes his thoughts on being asked to perform on Electric Horseman -- (36:23) Nelson reveals to Collie that Honeysuckle Rose was actually originally written for Hoyt Axton and not himself -- (37:05) Nelson gives his thoughts on the stability through both the movie and music industries -- (37:50) Nelson reveals the non-story of Candice Bergen and Jane Fonda -- (38:29) Nelson tells of how he did not believe remembering lines to be difficult, but the waiting took its toll on Nelson -- (39:23) "Angel Flying to Close to the Ground" and "Healing Hands of Time" are revealed to be two of Nelson's favorite songs he recorded, but Nelson is unsure of the reason behind his enjoyment. Nelson reflects on how he wrote the "On the Road Again" lyrics quickly for Honeysuckle Rose -- (40:18) Nelson describes the image he wanted for the "On the Road Again" melody and how challenge writing is his most memorable -- (40:53) Collie has Nelson reflect on his favorite records and Collie and Nelson discuss how Nelson would play "Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain" in clubs -- (42:02) Collie has Nelson describe the albums he recorded with RCA records with the greatest cultural significance -- (42:24) Nelson describes his reasoning for leaving the Grand Ole Opry -- (43:15) Collie and Nelson discuss how Nelson enjoys pretty much every aspect of traveling on the road except the over-abundance of security -- (44:40) Nelson says "About 30, sounds, lights, concessions" -- (44:49) Collie discusses and event that gave a number of people a job, Nelson likens it to a time Elvis Presley did the same, and Nelson discusses how he enjoys giving people he knows a job -- (46:03) Collie has Nelson reflect on how Jimmy Carter and Nelson were friends -- (46:24) Nelson tells about a time that Carter asked Nelson if he remembered the the words to the "Star Spangled Banner" -- (46:41) Charlie Pride is told by Nelson as a risky endeavor when he first put Pride on his show -- (48:19) Leon Russell is described by Nelson to be the greatest entertainer Nelson had ever met -- (48:43) Collie and Nelson talk about how Nelson and Russell's album went platinum -- (49:00) Paul English is described by Nelson to be his closest friend -- (49:26) Nelson describes how he and Kris Kristofferson worked in different parts of Nashville -- (50:11) Nelson reflects on his appreciation for Tompall Glaser -- (50:32) Collie has Nelson describe an outlaw; Nelson describes and outlaw as someone who goes against the established norm and he lists a number of people he believes to be original outlaws -- (51:26) Darrell Royal is described by Nelson to be the "greatest country music fan in the world" -- (51:50) Nelson briefly says praise of Hank Cochran -- (52:17) Nelson describes how he worked for Ray Price and his eventual opportunity to play bass in Price's band -- (52:57) Collie has Nelson reflect on his religious backing and Nelson reflects on how he was fired from being a Sunday school teacher -- (54:32) Collie and Nelson joke about preaching and Nelson tells how he believes in reincarnation, linking it to being in a university -- (56:16) "Precious Memories" is revealed to be Nelson's favorite hymn -- (56:28) Collie and Nelson reflect on the difference having money makes -- (57:14) Nelson tells his ambition had always been music -- (57:39) Nelson says his first success was receiving money for performing -- (58:05) Nelson says Ray Charles was the most influential country music artist of all time, and Nelson puts the next in line to be Hank Williams -- (59:16) Collie and Nelson connect country to blues -- (59:37) Nelson links "Stardust" to "Hello Walls" to be expressions of mood -- (1:00:00) Nelson tells about a time playing at Caesar's Palace, and Nelson did not notice Bee Spears flying around on cable wire about his while playing "Angel Flying too Close to the Ground" -- (1:01:02) Collie and Nelson discuss hoe Nelson was unsure if he was going to quit music -- (1:01:21) Collie has Nelson reflect on the autobiographical nature of the songs he records
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Nelson, Willie, 1933-; Collie, Biff;
